I bought this game in 2003 just after it's release, now in 2014 I find myself still playing it just as much. A few things to know about this game:

THERE ARE NO BASES - There is something awfully appealing about having a certain ammount of units and being told to capture an area without reinforcements.

The Campaign is fairly repetitive after a while. Essentially you will end up doing similar convoy missions, town clearing missions, defend the gun emplacement missions etc to get upgraded tanks and artillery.

Without fail i have hit a point in every campaign where i need a break - Everytime i have played though it (more than two dozen times for each side) I will find that the missions get too repetitive and i need to play something else. I find that this game draws me back like a wasp to jam, and i need to take my units though the campaign so they can go home.

This game is a relic, it is from 2003, so don't expect fancy graphics, or elaborate game plots. This is exactly what it says on the tin, and without fail i would say that it is the best strategy game I have played. True, it has it's bad points, but every game does, but the magic i got when i first played this game is still there, and it's still worth playing!

I notice that i doesnt have much play time on record, truthfully i have sunk well over 1500 hours into this game, but having just bought it on Steam, i have yet to match this.

reviewText:
I actually own 3 physical copies of this game since 2003... now I own my 4th copy haha. I've remembered when it lagged frequently on my old compaq Pentium 4 computer lol

This game is so good that I still have my first physical copy installed since 2008 (wanted to play it during that time and it was only about ~800-900 mb so it doesn't tax on your hard drive at all). So since 2008, After playing all the mission that was offered in this game + expansion, I wanted to see if there were any modifications to this game to further enhance my imagination. My god, there was; mods like CSLA and ROK 1950 mod was the best that I've seen for this game and probably was the reason why I never deleted it. If you ever wanted to play this game but in a different time period (i.e. Korean War/Cold War) you should definitely try out the CSLA and ROK 1950s mod (the 'official' blitzkrieg mod forum was shut down [Bk portal] in 2009 but that place had everything, every custom map every mods were there and now its gone....) I'll post link to the mod in the comment (glad to see that the other old sites are still working). With this mod, I had so much fun in playing that I started making tweaks of my own to these mods especially combining these two mods together.

However, the issues that exist with these mods are that there is not many of the single player custom missions that comes with it (it takes alot of time scripting each units and making waypoints, such). So you are left with downloading other custom maps and making the missions on your own but again too much time. But these few missions have some memorable missions like the Fuldagap in the CSLA mod where you are holding off the Russian invasion into Western Germany with German and US forces (Of course TONS of new units, new Aircraft animations, helicopters as well).

Bottomline: Game is worth every cent, still play it (with mods too), my first WWII strategy game

reviewText:
I remember I saw Blitzkrieg as a kid and I nearly cried when I saw I didn't have a computer that could run it.

My first thought was that this looks suspiciosuly like Sudden Strike and then I saw it had the same developer which is why they seemed to have a lot of the same art assets. Sudden Strike was one of the most unforgiving RTSs I have ever played and it made little attempt to teach me how to play or any of its mechanics.

Blitzkrieg is kinder in that regard. They had a proper tutorial and explain the components of the game. They also have a much nicer campaign than Sudden Strike. Firstly each campaign starts with pretty much the same kind of level to kind of introduce you to how the game works so it doesn't matter which of the three factions (Allied, German, and Soviet) you choose. Another cool idea was that you pretty much always have the same units at the beginning of each level. You're given two sets of core units (three armored vehicles and three artillery). As you progress you'll unlock newer units and you can earn bonus units when you complete levels and often you'll have a hub where you'll have a few different missions to choose from each with a different bonus. So Blitzkrieg does reward you for picking what battles and what core assets you take with you into battle. Do you want long range artillery or maybe replace some with anti-tank guns? Do you want to gamble with the bonus vehicle you unlocked (which will be lost if it gets killed) or use something more expendible.

I was really surprised by all the things the campaigns had for me to think about.

Infantry is pretty flexible compared to Sudden Strike. Infantry was basically canon fodder in Sudden Strke. They're slow, die easily, most slowly if pinned down, and host of other things. Sudden Strike 2 did introduce the idea that if there was an officer you can order soldiers to stand or line down which was an improvement. Blitzkrieg however offers a wider range. By default infantry will behave like in Sudden Strike and stand by default and go prone if under fire. Or you can have them completely disregard incoming fire and charge your enemy which is actually how you're supposed to deal with enemies inside buildings or tanks. They also made them faster which makes them a lot more dangerous. Additionally infantry will be in 10 man squards by default and trucks can replenish squads which means it's often a better idea to use your infantry than risk your tanks.

They also reworked a lot of the air support options giving you tactial fighter bombers, good old carpet bombing, recon planes, paratroopers, and air supremacy fighters. This is where I have a complaint, they don't tell you what model planes so when I asked for a bombing run I got fighter bombers instead of bombers. They also don't tell you how many planes are available. I think there was a missed oppurtunity because in the hub this seems like something I should be able to control before the mission.

Blitzkrieg is a massive improvement over the Sudden Strike series (though I still love that game that didn't seem to like me very much) and is a lot fun for people who want an old school RTS or really love World War II. As someone who loves both I love this game.

reviewText:
This is a unique flavor of RTS in that it is more attuned for classical wargamers than the typical Company of Heroes crowd. It is much more slowly unfolding and presents a challenge which is equal parts movement and logistics. Armored units require not just repair but also ammunition which is itself delivered by support vehicles from points scattered around the map. Infantry is fragile yet can peel apart vehicles rather quickly. Engineers are not tasked with erecting full structures and instead focus on trenches, bridges, and mines. Artillery hinges on surprise and concealment. Air power is abstracted and for the most part consists of calling for recon and carpet bombing strongpoints. The campaign game is split between the Allied, Axis, and Soviet fronts.
The high attrition found in early missions may frustrate new players. Unit selection is difficult and I often find my clicks unresponsive. It is definetly slow-roasted though and brings something new to PC tactics other than simply unit balance. I recommend this to those who dislike the frantic pace found in most RTS games or looking for something with low system requirements.

Update: The game may become locked in high speed while the game speed hotkeys are both non-responsive and non-reassignable. If this happens, a restart should remedy it.
